pros: Well established business processes, HR, etc. Might not sound like a plus, but when certain things need to get done they happen lightning fast.

Easy to get lost in the bureaucracy. Performance reviews are maddening.
Advice to Management
Change your performance review process.

I was management for several years here and then left and went back for a short stint as a contractor. So this is based on several years working there in a management position.

This might not be true for all areas, but the company's big on consistency and one-size fits all, so I suspect it's a fair number. I can only speak to a handful of software development areas that I have experience with.

Middle management is hamstrung. They're at the mercy of budgets, strategic decisions, etc., which you would expect. One of the most maddening things about that is that performance evaluations are based on a curve. 

The expectation is that there will always be a percentage of a team that will be low performers and an even smaller percentage that will be high performers.

This means sometimes people can get a poor performance review and it has nothing to do with their actual performance. If you have a high functioning team somebody has to get the short straw.

This turns into a situation where the only way to be rewarded is to be perceived to have value by the immediate management, which usually is something that gets passed down from a higher level executive.

If you have two people and they're both really good performers but are doing different but complementary jobs, both of which are vital, the one who's going to be rated higher is the one whose value the manager understands.

If you have someone who came up through development as a manager, technical skill might be the only thing they really get and the person who has a deeper understanding of the business that allows the development to get done in the first place, enh, maybe not so much.

So even if your job is essential, if it doesn't fit management's perception of essential it's easy to be seen as a lower performer, regardless of what your actual job is.

And it's probably not because they hate you. A lot of the time it's because they don't know you well enough.

Anyway, advice to management, change your performance review process. I have seen nothing at that company that destroys morale more than that.
